Text.#text: EXAMINATION

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Good morning.
A     Good morning.
Q     Can you please state and spell your full
name for the record?
A     It's Marcell Escobar.  M-a-r-c-e-l-l
E-s-c-o, B as in boy, a-r.
Q     Do you have a middle name, sir?
A     My legal name is David Marcell Escobar.
Q     Have you ever had your deposition taken
before?
A     No.
Q     I'm going to go through the process with
you really quick.  You understand the court reporter
sitting to your right has placed you under oath?
A     Correct.
Q     Yes?
A     Yes.
Q     And that oath is under penalty of perjury?
A     Yes.
Q     So all your job is here today is just to
answer my questions truthfully and accurately; okay?
A     Yes.
Q     And my job is to ask good questions that
you understand; okay?
A     Yes.
Q     So, the court reporter is typing
everything down right now, and he's only able to
type down what one person is saying at a time.  So
just make sure, no matter how predictable my
questions are, and they will be, that you just wait
until I'm done asking before answering it; okay?
A     Yes.
Q     You're doing a good job right now, but the
court reporter also would have a hard time
documenting uh-huhs, uh-uhs, nods of the head,
shakes of the head, and while this is being
videotaped and we can see what you're saying, we
want to make sure that the record is clear as well.

Text.#text: So please make sure to state audible

Line.Text: responses; okay?
A     I will, thank you.
Q     And if you don't understand any question
I'm asking, let me know and I'll be happy to
rephrase it.
A     I'll do.
Q     But if you answer a question, it's
presumed you understood the question; fair?
A     Yes, thanks.
Q     At the end of this deposition, what's
going to happen is the court reporter is eventually
going to create a deposition transcript which is
going to have all your questions -- all my questions
and all your answers; okay?
A     Okay.
Q     And you're going to have a chance with
limited time to review your answers and make changes
to them; okay?
A     Okay.
Q     I want to caution you since you're here
and ready to provide your most truthful and accurate
testimony, if you make any substantive changes, then
that could be commented upon at the time of trial
and it may prove embarrassing to you; okay?
A     Right.
Q     Do you have any questions about the
process?
A     No, I don't.
Q     One other thing, there's no judge here, so
what lawyers may do is they may assert objections.
Those objections are for the record unless your
lawyer tells you not to answer.
A     Okay.
Q     So just wait until everybody asserts their
objections and then feel free to answer the pending
question; okay?
A     Very good.
Q     Why don't I go through your background
really quick.

Text.#text: You're a field supervisor for SoCal Gas?

Line.Text: A     Yes, sir.
Q     How long have you employed by SoCal Gas?
A     15 years.
Q     Who were you employed by before that?
A     Trader Joe's market.
Q     Before Trader Joe's?
A     Staples.
Q     Before Staples?
A     That's it.
Q     Your experience with the natural gas
industry started with SoCal Gas?
A     Yes, it did.
Q     Where did you go to high school?
A     Burbank High School, in Burbank,
California.
Q     When did you graduate?
Q     Did you go to college?
A     Yes, I did.
Q     Where did you go?
A     I attended Pasadena City College for
approximately three years.
Q     Did you obtain an AA?
A     Yes, I did.
Q     So '99?
A     Roughly.
Q     Did you go anywhere else after that?
A     University of La Verne.
Q     How long?
A     Approximately five years.
Q     Did you obtain a degree?
A     Yes, I did.
Q     In what?
A     Business administration.
Q     Roughly 2004?
A     No, it was this year.
Q     Oh, this year.
A     Yeah.
Q     Congratulations.
Q     So you started in '08?
A     It was -- yeah, 2008.
Q     Any other college?
A     No, that's all.
Q     How about any vocational training?
A     No.
Q     Where did you receive your training to
work at SoCal Gas?
A     The gas company, SoCal Gas Company, our
training facility.
Q     Prior to being employed by SoCal Gas, did
you have any training at all with the operation of
natural gas?
A     No, I did not.
Q     Or the maintenance of natural gas lines?
A     No, I did not.
Q     Or the maintenance of appliances that
utilized natural gas?
A     I did not.
Q     So, let's start.  When did you start at
SoCal Gas?
A     September of 1998.
Q     And you've been continuously employed
there since?
A     Yes.
Q     What was your first job?
A     It was a part-time meter reader.

Text.#text: MS. PAPE:  You said as a part-time meter

Line.Text: reader?

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  Meter reader, hmm-mm.

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     When did you first start as a part-time
meter reader?
A     September 1998.
Q     Did you receive any training before you
actually were out on the field actually reading
meters?
A     Yes.
Q     What type of training did you receive?
A     The standard meter reader training that
our training facility puts on, you know, to learn
how to read meters and identify hazardous conditions
out in the field as far as abnormal operating
conditions at the meters, our gas meters.  Safety
training, how to prevent dog bites because we're
going into yards, customers' premises, stuff like
that.
Q     Was the safety training, personal safety?
A     Yes.
Q     Was there safety training with respect to
maintaining gas lines at this point in time when you
became a part-time meter reader?
A     Not maintaining, no.
Q     Was there any safety training relating to
gas leaks at this point in time?
A     Very minimal.
Q     Can you give me an example of what they
taught you?
A     We were just taught that if we were on a
customer's premises and we smelled gas that we had
to call our dispatch office so they can dispatch a
fully qualified field technician to go out there and
assess it.
Q     Okay.  And after you -- what did you do
next for SoCal Gas?
A     I became a field technician, January of
Q     So, for two and a half years, you were a
part-time meter reader?
A     Correct.
Q     And then you were promoted to a field
technician in 2001?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     Okay.  Did you receive new training at
that point?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     At your facility?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     How long was the training?
A     Roughly five weeks.
Q     Generally, what were you taught -- what
areas or subject matters were you trained on?
A     We're trained on minor gas appliance
repair, identifying leakage on customers' premises.
Again, more safety training as far as body mechanics
because now we're working with tools and driving a
lot more so we received more driver's training.
Q     In your training --
A     Customer contact skills.
Q     Anything else?
A     Not that I can think of at the moment.
Q     In your training to become a field tech,
would you agree that there was an emphasis put on
ensuring no gas leakage?
A     Absolutely.
Q     And why is that?
A     Because we never want to put the public
in, you know, in jeopardy, and ourselves.
Q     So, in your training as a field
technician, you were trained to assess and identify
gas leaks when you first arrive at a residence;
correct?
A     Depending on the nature of the call.
Q     But you definitely want to keep that in
mind?
A     Absolutely.
Q     And then you always want to ensure that
there's no gas leaks before you leave a residence;
is that what you were trained?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Hold on a second.  We're

Line.Text: starting to kind of get far off field for the
purpose of the deposition.  He's here as the PMK
regarding investigations.  And albeit his background
is relevant for purposes of the deposition, but
you're now -- there is a lot of focus on company
policy with respect to training and things like
that, and that's starting to, again, get off field
from what he's here for today.

Text.#text: But I'll let him answer a few more

Line.Text: questions on the topic.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Do you remember the question?
A     Can you repeat it?
Q     You were trained -- in your training to be
a field tech, you were trained to ensure that there
were no gas leaks at the time you left a premise; is
that correct?
A     Correct.
Q     And that was important?
A     Yes.
Q     To ensure the safety of the public?
A     Yes.
Q     And the occupants of that --

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  We're talking about him

Line.Text: personally?

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  His training.
MR. WILLIAMS:  Personally?
MR. RAVIPUDI:  Yeah.
MR. WILLIAMS:  His personal training?
MR. RAVIPUDI:  Yeah.

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     And you were trained by SoCal Gas
because -- to ensure no leakages because you wanted
to ensure the safety of the people occupying that
premise; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     How long were you a field tech?
A     Field tech, approximately a year and two
or three months.
Q     So in early to middle 2002, what happened?
A     I became an energy technician, which is an
upgrade to the field technician.
Q     What additional responsibilities did you
have as an energy technician?
A     Additional, we conducted high-bill
investigations, customer service orders, leak
investigations.
Q     How long were you an energy technician?
A     Approximately five years.
Q     I didn't ask this but what were your job
duties as a field technician?
A     Field technician mostly was showing up to
the customer's home and turning on the gas when they
move in.  Restoring the gas when they were shut off
for nonpayment.  Restoring their gas service when
our distribution department did maintenance work
outside in our facilities that they shut the gas
off, so we would restore it.

Text.#text: So we would turn on the gas at the

Line.Text: customer's premise and enter the home and verify
that all the equipment is working, all the gas
appliances were working properly and safely.
Q     What training did you receive on leak
investigations as an energy technician?
A     We have a -- our leak investigation policy
and, again, depending on the nature of the call, we
have different procedures as to what we -- what we
check.
Q     I see.  So when you're talking about a
leak investigation, it could be a customer
complaint?
A     Yes.
Q     They smell gas and you come in and
investigate?
A     Yes.
Q     How about -- you understand why you're
here today; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     When you were at the scene of -- after the
house had caught fire, is that a leak investigation?
A     Not in our records.  I wasn't sent out
there to do a leak investigation.  It just -- it
turned into a leak investigation.
Q     When did it turn into a leak
investigation?
A     When we opened the gas meter -- when I say
"we," my field technician that was out there, the
first one, Craig Allen -- when he opened the gas
meter, I noticed that -- well, both of us noticed
that gas was escaping somewhere based on looking at
the meter dial.
Q     And at that point in time, when you opened
up the gas meter and noticed that the dial was
moving, you realized gas was escaping?
A     Absolutely.
Q     And then at that point it became a leak
investigation?
A     I would say so, yes.
Q     And the training you received in leak
investigation before becoming an energy technician,
that's the same -- you used that same leak
investigation policy in analyzing this accident?
A     Yes.
Q     So it's a written policy?
A     Yes.
Q     Where is it located?
A     In our policies and procedures.  There's a
standard number that I don't know right off the top
of my head.
Q     Did you bring it with you here today?
A     No, I did not.
Q     Are you familiar --

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  For the record, I believe

Line.Text: it's been produced in the case already.

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Okay.  It's been produced?

Line.Text: So maybe I'll put it out at some point in time.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     How thick is the leak investigation
policy?
A     I couldn't tell you.  It's not -- I would
say maybe 20 some odd pages on a Word document.
Q     What's the basic -- what's your basic
understanding of SoCal Gas's leak investigation
policy?
A     Basic understanding of it?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  You want a description or

Line.Text: an understanding?

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  How he understands.
MR. WILLIAMS:  Do you want him to describe

Line.Text: what it is?

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Not the document.
MR. WILLIAMS:  No, no, no, I know.

Line.Text: Describing the policy --

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Yeah.
MR. WILLIAMS:  -- as opposed to his under-
MR. RAVIPUDI:  Yeah.
MR. WILLIAMS:  Can you give him a general

Line.Text: overview of what the leak investigation policy would
entail?

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  It's difficult to summarize.

Line.Text: There's a lot of stuff in there, but, you know, the
gist of it is we're responsible to identify, you
know, to our very best, leakage on a customer's
facility and our own facilities out on the street
and take the proper action to get them repaired.

Text.#text: Many times, a customer has a leak on their

Line.Text: proper gas piping system in their house, and at that
point, we don't do any repairs on that.  We leave
their meter off and refer them to a plumber so they
can have that fixed.  But regardless, we leave it
safe.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Okay.  How much time was spent training
you on leak investigations before you became an
energy tech?
A     I don't remember.
Q     How many leak investigations have you done
for SoCal Gas over your career?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  This is an estimate, he is

Line.Text: entitled to it, if you can give him an estimate.  If
you don't have an exact number, we understand.  But
if you can give him a ballpark.

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  If I was out there -- I was

Line.Text: out there on my job five years -- wow...

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  And he's asked you your

Line.Text: entire time; correct?  Not just when he was an
energy --
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Yeah, your entire career.
A     Maybe 500.
Q     So you know how to investigate leaks?
A     Yes.
Q     2007, you finished becoming an energy
technician, what did you do next?
A     At that point, I stepped into the
management side of SoCal Gas and my first position
was a region application specialist in our
Chatsworth dispatch office.
Q     As a region application specialist, are
you ever out in the field?
A     No.
Q     What do you do as a region application
specialist?
A     We support the dispatch office, and then
dispatch and applications, support our field
technicians on their mobile data terminals, which
are the computers that they use out in their trucks.
So basically, we're -- we work behind the scenes to
make sure the communications are running smoothly
between the dispatchers and the field techs.
Q     Did you supervise any field techs in this
capacity?
A     I did not.
Q     How long were you a region application
specialist?
A     About ten months.
Q     So roughly early 2008?
A     May of -- May or June of 2008.
Q     Okay.  What was your new job in May or
June of 2008?
A     Quality assurance specialist.
Q     What's that?
A     Quality assurance specialist, it's our
quality control department so we go out behind the
field technicians after they complete service orders
at customers' homes and we just go out there and
review their work and make sure the employee
followed all company procedures and policies.
Q     So you're spot checking?
A     Pretty much.
Q     Is there a methodology for doing that at
SoCal Gas?
A     Yes, we go out there no more than 14 days
after the employee has visited the customer's
property and we don't make appointments, we just
show up unannounced.
Q     Now, is there a percentage of spot checks
you do per service tech?
A     Yeah, there's a whole system that I'm not
too familiar with because that was our -- our senior
quality assurance person's responsibility was to
keep track of all the field technicians, and they
were supposed to be checked on a certain amount of
elements per year per employee.
Q     So as a quality assurance specialist,
you're supervising to say, Hey, go to this
address --
A     Pretty much.
Q     -- check to see what's going on?
A     Yeah, they would just route us and we do
it.
Q     What materials would you have with you
before going to a person's home or premises?
A     Materials, we only carried a clipboard
with our paper order.  We didn't carry tools.  We
weren't there to make any adjustments or do any work
on the customer's property.
Q     Was there some material that you'd
received giving you information as to what the field
service tech did?
A     Yes.
Q     So would you have that in hard copy or on
your computer?
A     It was a hard copy.  It was a printed
copy.
Q     Would it be the dispatch request and then
the actual activity of the service tech that day?
A     It was the order instructions of what the
employee was there for and everything that he
documented on his order.  It got printed on that
order.
Q     How long did you do this?
A     About 12 months.
Q     On average, how many spot checks would you
do a week or a month?  What's the best way for you
to estimate?
A     About maybe ten or 15 a day.  A lot of
times, it was difficult to get into places because
customers weren't expecting us so we had a lot of
customers not home.  Maybe 200 to 250 a week.
Q     What happens when you find or determine
that the field service tech didn't do what they were
supposed to?
A     We document it.
Q     How do you document it?
A     We -- at the job site, we just take notes,
benefits -- you know, if it's an unsatisfactory
condition to where the employee should have left a
hazardous notice or unsatisfactory condition notice
to the customer, then we'll write it up at that
point and then we'll issue it to the customer.

Text.#text: But, usually, we just jot it down, notes,

Line.Text: and then we would create an electronic report at the
end of the day.
Q     What's the name of that electronic report?
A     I don't remember what it was called.
Q     Is it something that ends up in the file
of the service tech?
A     Eventually, yes.
Q     What's done with your electronic report?
A     We would e-mail it to our senior QA
specialist.
Q     To your knowledge, what would your senior
QA specialist do with it?
A     They review it, make sure that, you know,
it's accurate based on our interpretation of policy
that was not followed out there.  And then it was
their job to e-mail it to the local district
supervisor of those employees.
Q     And, then, to your knowledge, what does
the local district supervisor do with a -- with the
document or information?
A     Usually, they'll call on the employee and
discuss the error.
Q     Does your -- do your findings -- strike
that.

Text.#text: In your capacity as a quality assurance

Line.Text: specialist, have any of your findings resulted in
discipline to field service techs?
A     We never hear back on that.
Q     So you don't know exactly what the outcome
is?
A     No.
Q     Roughly May or June 2009, did you get
promoted?
A     Yes.
Q     To what?
A     To field operations supervisor.
Q     Is that what you are now?
A     Yes.
Q     What are your jobs as a field operations
supervisor?
A     Monitor our field technicians, we conduct
field rides where we get in the truck with them and
we go out and do service orders or observe them
perform service orders.  We monitor their quality,
their efficiency, their production.
Q     What territory did you cover?
A     At that --

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Vague as to time.
MR. RAVIPUDI:  Yeah.
MR. WILLIAMS:  Do you want to give him a

Line.Text: time?
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     If it changed over time, just walk me
through.
A     It changed.
Q     All right.
A     At that time, I was in Alhambra,
California.

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  And you say -- by "at that

Line.Text: time," you mean when you first became --

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  When I first became a field

Line.Text: operations supervisor.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     For how long were you covering the
Alhambra territory?
A     Approximately three and a half years.
Q     So relatively recently changed?
A     Yes, in January of this year.
Q     Which territory do you cover now?
A     Oxnard.
Q     How many field service techs did you need
to supervise, and during the three and a half year
time in Alhambra.
A     Roughly had -- directly, I had 11.
Indirectly, because I shared them with my
counterpart, 22, so we split them down the middle.
Q     So there were 22 field service techs in
your time in Alhambra that covered that territory?
A     Yes.
Q     And then there were two field operations
supervisors for that territory?
A     Yes.
Q     And you were one of them?
A     Yes.

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Just to be clear, when

Line.Text: you're saying 22, you mean typically, there were 22,
not 22 the entire time; correct?  Because people --

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  Yeah, people leave, people

Line.Text: get upgraded but that's --
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     On average?
A     On average, it was about 22.
Q     Simon Youde, do you know who he is?
A     Yes.
Q     Who was he?
A     He was one of our energy technicians.
Q     Did you supervisor them?
A     Yes, I did.
Q     Is that why you were called to this
particular scene?
A     I was called there because I'm the
supervisor.  It wasn't because I was Simon's
supervisor.
Q     You were a supervisor for the territory?
A     Yes.
Q     What was the purpose of your arrival
there?
A     Typically, when there's a structure fire,
the fire department calls the Gas Company to secure
our gas facilities.
Q     So your arrival there was in response to,
essentially, the fire department's call for service?
A     Yes.
Q     Did you document your time there?
A     There's nothing official, no.  Supervisors
aren't required to, you know, create any
documents -- I mean, we do contact -- our dispatch
office does contact us once we're done and they ask
us for our arrival and departure, but that's really
the only documentation I can think of.
Q     Gotcha.  All right.  I've marked as
Exhibit 1, this is the deposition notice.

Text.#text: (Deposition Exhibit 1, deposition notice,
was marked for identification by the
certified Shorthand Reporter and is
attached hereto.)

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     You've seen this document before,
Exhibit 1?
A     No.
Q     Do you understand you're here today as a
person most qualified for SoCal Gas to talk about an
inspection of the premises after the incident?
A     Yes.
Q     And with respect to the premises, we're
referring to the 1776 West Marshall Street in
San Gabriel, California.

A     Yes.

would be documented, really, on 2-D?

Smell of natural G" -- natural gas?

Mr. Allen --

Q     -- who got there at 2:59?

BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Do you recall when you roughly arrived?
A     Roughly 3:15.
Q     Okay.  Tell me -- walk me through your
investigation.
A     When I arrived, I met with Craig Allen.
He stated that when he arrived, that he found the
gas meter was turned off by the fire department.
So, we stayed put for a few minutes, we didn't want
to start any investigation yet because they were
busy going back and forth, the fire department.

Text.#text: Several minutes later, we opened the meter

Line.Text: so we turned on the valve -- or he turned on the
valve to the meter, and we noticed that the dial was
moving quite rapidly.  So we knew that there was an
escape of gas somewhere so we shut it off
immediately.

Text.#text: So we proceeded to walk around the

Line.Text: premise, the main house in the front, looking for
any obvious signs of an open gas line.  We also made
an attempt to go to the back where the damage was,
briefly looked, but there was a lot of rubbage
[sic], a lot of water.  We didn't really see
anything, you know, that was obvious back there.

Text.#text: So my first impression was that there was

Line.Text: an open gas line likely in the area of the damage
that the fire department caused while they were
putting it out.

Text.#text: So we stayed put.  Again, we were trying

Line.Text: to -- I was speaking with the fire captain, trying
to determine a cause because, in essence, the Gas
Company likes to learn what the cause of structure
fires are.  And originally, I was told that it was
probably an electrical fire that was caused there
due to the other unsafe conditions that they noticed
while they were there as far as wiring and a lot of
other, you know, unsatisfactory not-up-to-code
conditions that both structures had.
Q     Okay.  And so you stayed put until the
fire department left?
A     We stayed put, I let -- I let Craig Allen
go because we still had other work that needed to be
completed out in the field so I didn't want to hold
him up there.

Text.#text: The fire department was there, the

Line.Text: building -- or the code inspector was there.  Some
other officials were there.  And they didn't really
seem like we were going to be able to do a lot at
that point.

Text.#text: So he left the gas off, locked up the

Line.Text: meter, secured it and I let him go, but I stayed --
I stayed there on site.
Q     Then what happened?
A     Trying -- trying to get like a positive
confirmation as to what the cause was.
Q     Okay.  So what did you do next to
investigate the cause?
A     So I called -- I called Manny Meza, our
claims rep, and I informed him that it looks like
it's electrical in nature, the cause of the fire.
So, he had me stay there and he wanted us to try to
obtain a secure, what we call a clock test, which is
our leak test through the meter of the customer's
gas house piping to ensure that there are no gas
leaks.  So he wanted us to try our best to obtain
that before we left that night.
Q     And did you?
A     We -- at the end, yes.
Q     So when you say at the end, was that when
Steven Kimura was there?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     Who performed the secure clock test?
A     Steven Kimura, he did most of the work, I
assisted him.
Q     When you say a secure clock test, is that
the same type of leak test that is done by field
service techs when they leave a premises after
servicing them?
A     It's one of our methods.
Q     Are there other methods of doing a leak
test other than the secure clock test?
A     We use electronic leak detection
equipment, which is like a gas sniffer, and if we're
able to determine that's, you know, our -- the cause
of the leak and we were able to repair it, then the
clock test isn't required.  But a clock test is
required anytime that we don't determine the source
or we feel that there's more leakage there than what
we found and then repaired.
Q     How do you do a secure clock test?
A     A clock test is -- it's -- we utilize the
meter, the meter has a test dial that we mark, and
it needs to stay on the same position once we open
the gas.  And we run the test for two minutes and we
need to make sure that the dial didn't move in those
two minutes.  Therefore, we know there's no leakage
in the piping system.
Q     So you did that at the end of
January 19th?
A     Yes.
Q     Is there a document reflecting the
results?
A     Steven Kimura's order, 2-B, it -- it's not
specified there, but in the order instructions, it
does specify, "Clock test per" and "Escobar," which
is me, and so that's the reason why he was sent out
there, but it seems like he didn't document that at
the end of his order.
Q     What were the results?
A     At the end?
Q     Yeah.
A     We were able to get a secure clock test.
No movement.
Q     What does that mean?
A     That the test dial hand did not move after
two minutes.
Q     Okay.  So were you able -- and then what
else did you do that day to investigate the leak?
A     Okay.  So, after I had Steven Kimura
arrive, we -- he would open the gas a little bit, I
didn't want to have it open too long because I knew
there was gas escaping somewhere.  So, I had him at
the meter and he would open the gas slowly to where,
you know, the leak would start up and I was walking
around the premises with an electronic gas sniffer
trying to determine more or less the area of the
leak.

Text.#text: So we did -- we conducted that for, I

Line.Text: would say, maybe close to 45 minutes or so.
Q     Were you able to find the area of the
leak?
A     No.
Q     So after 45 minutes of using the gas
sniffer, you weren't able to find the area of the
leak even though the dial was reflecting there was
gas flowing?
A     I didn't determine the area of the --
where the gas was actually escaping, no.
Q     What were you able to determine by using
the sniffer?
A     I determined a valve that stopped the leak
that I found in the back portion of the front house
in the -- in like the service porch area.
Q     Did you photograph that valve?
A     That's depicted in SCG 00417 of the
pictures.
Q     So, why don't we do this.

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  And the pictures do have

Line.Text: Bates numbers on them.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     So Exhibit 2 [sic] we don't have to have
my bad writing on them since they're already Bates
stamped SCG 00393 all the way through 421; correct?
Is that correct, the photographs?
A     The photographs, yes.  00418 shows a
closeup.
Q     And you took all of the photographs in
Exhibit 4?
A     Yes, I did.
Q     000418, there's a yellow knob and a bunch
of tubing?
A     Yes.
Q     Is this next to the water heater?
A     Yes, it is.
Q     Is this valve after you turned it to the
"off" position?
A     Yes, it is.
Q     And when you first saw it, the valve was
in the "on" position?
A     Yes, it was.
Q     Looking at the work orders, which is
Exhibit 2, that morning, Mr. Youde was there to
service the water heater?
A     Mr. Youde was originally called out there
because the customer called in that their gas had
gone out.  When he arrived, he determined that the
automatic earthquake shutoff valve that was
installed on their gas meter, which is the
customer's property, it doesn't belong to us, had
been tripped.  Therefore, the gas was off, so it was
probably bumped into where the trash can or
something that caused it to move and that's what
caused the gas to go out.
Q     That's not an unusual event for that to
happen?
A     No, it happens a lot.
Q     So he was there to basically restore the
gas?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     In doing so, he also restored the water
heater; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     Okay.  So now, you, in this 45-minute
period, you were able to at least -- strike that.

Text.#text: Were you -- did you identify this open

Line.Text: valve in the 45 minutes you were walking around with
the gas sniffer?
A     Yes, I did.
Q     And then you turned that dial and the gas
stopped?
A     Yes.
Q     Or the meter stopped spinning?
A     Yes, it did.
Q     Did that assist you in your determination
of the cause?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  The cause of?
MR. RAVIPUDI:  The gas fire.
THE WITNESS:  It helped me in the

Line.Text: determination where the gas was leaking.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Okay.
A     I figured it's leaking downstream, which
is, you know, that pipe goes -- that valve serves
gas going into the pipe that goes in the ground,
likely going to the back.  And once I turned that
valve, the gas flow, wherever it was going, stopped.
Q     Okay.  What other investigation did you do
on January 19th?
A     I believe that was it.
Q     So, after you were able to shut off the
valve depicted in SCG 418, Exhibit 4, then you did a
secure clock test and confirmed that there was no
more gas leaking?
A     Absolutely.
Q     So at least your goal for that day was
accomplished?
A     Yes.
Q     And then you were always trying to
determine the cause while you were there; correct?
A     Right.
Q     And this identification of the open valve
depicted on 418 assisted you in determining the
cause of the gas fire; correct?
A     Yes.

because this is Exhibit 2.

Line.Text: The diagram.

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  Yes, three.

MR. RAVIPUDI:  Four, correct.

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     So walk me through your diagramming of
Exhibit 3.
A     Okay.  Exhibit 3, I made the sketch of
what I encountered while I was out there as far as
gas appliances, water heater, where it was located,
gas pipe in the rear of the front house, the garage,
or the front portion of the garage which was a
storage unit, and then the actual live-in portion of
that conversion.  I put down the -- that I found a
connector.  There was also a line valve, a half-inch
gas line.
Q     And that's at the back of the house?
A     That's in the -- in the rear.  This is in
the portion of the -- of where the fire occurred.
Q     When you pointed to this -- so what we've
got here is West Marshall Street on the bottom of
Exhibit 3; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     And you're orientating the document that
way.

Text.#text: And then the first square box -- you've

Line.Text: got 116, and that's intended to be the address for
the entire premises?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     And then you've got a square box to kind
of the right middle, which is the main house?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     And in there, you identified the
refrigerator, water heater, and back door?
A     Yes.
Q     Is there a reason why those were the only
three things you identified?
A     Because the location of the -- of the live
valve that was supplying gas to that rear portion of
the property was situated in that corner next to
that water heater, and that refrigerator somewhat
restricted the view of that -- of that corner, those
valves.
Q     I see.  So when you prepared this diagram,
it was after you discovered the valve --
A     Yes.
Q     -- that was open, leading to the back
house?
A     Yes.
Q     Okay.  And then, in the upper left-hand
corner is another rectangle which is intended to
depict the back house where the gas fire occurred;
right?
A     Correct.
Q     Is everything that you've documented in
Exhibit 3 photographed?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  So you're including the

Line.Text: street and the driveway as well or?

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Well, really, I'm looking

Line.Text: at --

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  The structures?

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Yeah, the structures.

Text.#text: Like if you're identifying, for example,

Line.Text: the storage unit here, is there a corresponding
photograph of the storage unit?
A     Maybe not from outside like the whole
structure, but there are portions of that storage
unit, maybe the inside.  I think one of those photos
depicts that.
Q     Okay.  So you identified on the back of
the main house a half-inch steel gas pipeline into
the concrete?
A     In the back of the main house, yes, sir.
Q     And it was your impression that that led
to the back house; correct?
A     Yes.

Text.#text: MS. PAPE:  Let me just make an objection

Line.Text: for the record.  There's been reference to a back
house, whether there's any evidence that there is a
back house, it's always been referred to as the
garage area.

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Okay.

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     And then, you've got documented for --
just for simplicity, we'll call it the rear
structure; is that okay?
A     That's fine.
Q     In the rear structure, you've put an "X"
and said no dryer?
A     Yes.
Q     Is there a reason why you documented that?
A     If I recall correctly, there was a gas
line there.  And also what -- it appeared to be like
a washer -- or there was a washer, because I have it
right there, "Washer outside."  But there was no
dryer hooked up.
Q     Do you have --
A     And I don't believe there's a photograph
of that.
Q     And then you saw -- you identified the
door to the one partitioned area of the rear
structure?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     And then you also identified some pipes on
the outside of this rear structure?
A     Yes.
Q     Describe to me what you identified.
A     There was a half-inch steel gas line that
ran parallel along the outside wall.  And there was
a valve, also, that we call a line valve, and
there's a connector, which is a gas-carrying
flexible connector at the end of that that was just
dangling there.
Q     Were you able to reach any determination
as to whether this half-inch gas line was connected
to the meter?
A     That particular one, it was assumed that
it was because the half-inch steel line that goes
into the ground behind the front structure, just
inside of that, you have that valve that I found
open.  And once I turned that off, the meter stopped
moving, so -- the meter dial hand stopped moving, so
it was my determination that there was the escape of
gas downstream of this location here where that pipe
goes into the ground.
Q     What did you write here, "Discovered after
removing plywood section outside the kitchen
window"?

Text.#text: What are you referring to?

Line.Text: A     On the 19th, in the area of where it says,
"Disconnect -- tee and disconnected pipe," it
appeared like there was some -- a wood panelling
that was blocking, that had been set there prior.
And it was, if I recall correctly, and I think it's
depicted in some of these photos, that it's blocking
a window.  And the day of, the 19th, when I was
there, I didn't notice that because those panels
were still up.

Text.#text: On the 20th, when we returned, a portion

Line.Text: of those panels were off.  They were removed and
that's when I could see better that this gas line
existed in there.
Q     I see.  So it's really on the 20th that
you were able to ascertain and identify the gas line
leading from the main house all the way into the
rear structure where you've got the kitchen counter
identified?
A     Yes.
Q     And then that's when you were able to
reach the conclusion that the opening of the gas
line by the water heater resulted in the leakage of
gas into the rear structure, near the kitchen
counter?
A     Yes.
Q     Did I cover everything you did and learn
on January 19th?
A     Yes.
Q     Tell me what happened on January 20th
relative to your investigation.
A     On the 20th, I returned to the scene to
meet our claims rep, Manny Meza.  And we met there,
it was approximately 1:00 p.m.  And he had --

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  You can talk about what you

Line.Text: did, but not what you talked about.

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  Okay.
MR. RAVIPUDI:  Just so the record is clear

Line.Text: and I don't lose any of my rights here --

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Sure.
MR. RAVIPUDI:  -- you're going to instruct

Line.Text: the witness not to answer as to any dialogue he had
directly with Mr. Meza?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  With claims, yes.
MR. RAVIPUDI:  And any dialogue Mr. Meza

Line.Text: had with him?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Correct.
Now, what he did when he was there, that's

Line.Text: fine.

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Okay.

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Carry on.
A     So that day we called out Simon Youde back
to the scene.
Q     Do you recall approximately what time
Mr. Youde arrived at the scene?  Feel free to tell
us what page you're looking at when you find it.
A     Yes, sir.

Text.#text: 3:58 p.m., and that's 2-E.

Line.Text: Q     How long was he there that day?
A     He departed at 5:24 p.m. as stated in 2-F.
Q     Carry on with telling me what you did that
day.
A     So we conducted the leak investigation, so
we could formally have it on record since it wasn't
conducted to its full documentation the previous
night.  So this was claims' request that we go ahead
and conduct a full leak investigation.

Text.#text: So when he arrived, we did a walk-through

Line.Text: of the premises and checked, did a visual inspection
of the gas appliances at the front structure, at the
house.

Text.#text: So we looked at the range, the water

Line.Text: heater.  I believe they had a wall furnace, and they
also had a fireplace.
Q     Describe the full inspection of these four
appliances.
A     He made sure that all the connections, the
gas connections to these appliances were correct, no
improper fittings.  That's part of our standard
service.

Text.#text: We make sure that all of the top burner

Line.Text: valves are turned off, make sure everything is in
the "off" position, so when we go to the meter and
open the gas, there's no escape of gas.  So this is
just a preliminary investigation prior to opening
the gas meter.

Text.#text: So we did that -- the four appliances he

Line.Text: checked that day.
Q     And in the four --
A     -- prior to opening the gas.
Q     Got it.

Text.#text: So prior to opening the gas, Mr. Youde

Line.Text: confirmed that the gas connections to the range,
water heater, wall furnace, and fireplace were
correct; right?
A     He did determine that there were brass
flex connectors, which are the flexible connectors
on the fireplace, the wall furnace, and the one that
the fireplace was going through, the fireplace wall,
which is an unsatisfactory condition in our
standards.
Q     So when he actually did a full inspection
of the appliances, he found that there were
unsatisfactory conditions at the fireplace and wall
furnace?
A     Yes.
Q     Other than finding unsatisfactory
conditions at the fireplace and wall furnace, he
confirmed that all the other gas connections were
correct?
A     Yes.
Q     And other than that -- I assume that brass
connectors at the fireplace and wall furnace are
types of fittings?
A     It's the flexible connector that connects
from the appliance to the gas valve that opens and
closes the gas.
Q     So other than finding those two brass
connectors on the fireplace and wall furnace to be
unsatisfactory, he confirmed that all the other
fittings were proper; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     And then he confirmed that the top burner
valves on the stove top --
A     Yes.
Q     -- were off?
A     Yes.
Q     And then you guys went to the meter?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     Then what happened?
A     Then he proceeded to open the gas and
conduct his clock test, his leak investigation to
where he was able to obtain a positive clock test
with no -- resulting in no leakage.
Q     Okay.  Then what did you do?
A     Then, we entered the home and he performed
service on -- first on the range, so he ignited all
the top burners, and the oven, made sure it was
working properly, which it was.
Q     Okay.  Then what?
A     He did the same for the water heater, and
it was working properly as well.
Q     Okay.  What else?
A     And also to the wall furnace, which was
also working properly.
Q     Then what else?
A     That was it inside the house.

Text.#text: Then he proceeded to address the

Line.Text: unsatisfactory conditions that were determined
during his preliminary inspection, then he filled
out the notice of unsatisfactory conditions to issue
to the customer.
Q     And those are Exhibits what?
A     Is that "G"?
Q     It's a "G."  That's why I was smiling
earlier because it's so terrible.
A     J through N.
Q     J through N are the notices of
unsatisfactory conditions completed by Mr. Youde
after his full inspection?
A     Yes.
Q     And you were flipping through papers
earlier and I just want to make sure I get it on the
record.

Text.#text: When Mr. Youde inspected the range, water

Line.Text: heater, and wall furnace, and fireplace, during his
full inspection, are those documented on any part of
Exhibit 2?
A     Yes.  The -- "E" is his order.
Q     Tell me what else you did in conducting
leak investigation on the 20th.
A     I believe that was it for that day.
Q     Did you talk to Mr. Youde about his
opening of the -- the gas line depicted in 418 of
Exhibit 2?
A     Yes, I did.
Q     Tell me about that.
A     I spoke to him prior to his arrival there,
the following morning, and I had him walk me through
what he did while he was on the service order.  And
he did state that he opened that valve.
Q     So, during his service of 116 Marshall
Street on the 19th, he opened the gas valve depicted
in 418, Exhibit 2, 418?
A     Yes.
Q     And it's also a further back picture of
that same valve as 417?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     Tell me more about that discussion with
him about opening the gas line.

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  I'll object on the grounds

Line.Text: that the question as phrased is vague.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Did you have any other discussion with him
about opening the gas line after he told you he
opened it?
A     I did -- I --

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Are you talking about that

Line.Text: day?
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Let me make it broader for you, okay?
A     Yes.
Q     And just so we can get a complete record.

Text.#text: Did you at any time have any discussion

Line.Text: with -- let me ask it differently.

Text.#text: How many times did you have a discussion

Line.Text: with Mr. Youde about him opening up the gas line?
A     Once.
Q     And is that one conversation the one that
you've already been talking about, the morning of
the 20th?
A     Yes.
Q     Before he arrived there?
A     Yes.
Q     During that conversation, you've already
told us that he told you he opened up that gas
line --
A     Yes.
Q     -- on the 19th?
A     Yes.
Q     Did he tell you anything else?
A     Why I asked him why he opened that valve,
and he stated that while he was trying to relight
the water heater, he had four failed attempts of
lighting the pilot, so he assumed that the valve was
closed.

Text.#text: And being that the refrigerator was really

Line.Text: close to that water heater and the water heater was
actually turned at an angle towards the
refrigerator, he wasn't able to get into that corner
to actually see the valve.  But when he stuck his
arm and his hand in there, he felt the valve -- a
valve was closed.

Text.#text: Typically, a gas appliance only has one

Line.Text: valve that supplies the -- that controls the gas to
the appliance.  So his assumption was that that was
the valve to the water heater.

Text.#text: And because it was closed, that's why he

Line.Text: wasn't able to light it.  So he proceeded to open
the valve and on his first attempt to relight that
water heater, it did light.
Q     So he told you that when he was -- he was
unsuccessful on four attempts to relight the water
heater?
A     Yes.
Q     And then he told you that he wasn't able
to see behind where the valve was located so he just
reached around?
A     Right.
Q     And then opened a valve that he felt was
closed?
A     Yes.
Q     What else did he tell you about his
service that day or anything related to opening that
valve?
A     I asked him if he returned to the meter to
verify that there -- it wasn't any leakage, and he
stated that he had not, that he did not return to
the meter.

Text.#text: When I asked him why not, he didn't have

Line.Text: an answer.  He said he didn't know.
Q     What else, if anything, about that?
A     That was it for that conversation with
him.
Q     Is that the entirety of your conversation
with him before he arrived?
A     Before he arrived, yes.
Q     And after he arrived, did you have any
further conversation with him about his actions in
servicing the property on the 19th?
A     Not that I recall.
Q     As a field service -- strike that.

Text.#text: As an energy technician servicing a home,

Line.Text: was Mr. Youde trained to check the meter before he
leaves the premises?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  I'm going to object on the

Line.Text: grounds that's beyond the scope of the subject
matter that the witness is here to testify
concerning today and I'm instructing him not to
answer.

Text.#text: (Instruction not to answer.)

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Did you reach a conclusion in your
investigation?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  As to what?
MR. RAVIPUDI:  As to the cause of the

Line.Text: structure fire.

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  I reached an assumption.

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Based on the information you had?
A     Yes.
Q     The information being that you found an
open line, you knew there was a gas fire in the rear
structure, and Mr. Youde telling you he opened up
that line?
A     Yes.
Q     And didn't check the meter; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     And that's the information that you needed
to reach your assumption or conclusion; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     And your findings in this matter were that
Mr. Youde's opening of the line and failing to check
the meter resulted in a gas leak in the back house
which ultimately led to the fire; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     Did you prepare any documents other than
what you might have done to Exhibit 3, on the 20th?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  You're talking about

Line.Text: relating to his investigation, not just did he
produce any?

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Yeah, relating to this.
THE WITNESS:  I believe I -- I created a

Line.Text: synopsis of my findings that my boss had asked me
for.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Who's your boss?
A     And I had sent it to her.

Text.#text: Darlene Corey.

Line.Text: Q     What's Darlene Corey's job title?
A     At the time or now?
Q     At the time.
A     District operations manager.
Q     What is she now?
A     She went to a different department.  She's
a manager of some sort, but I'm not exactly sure
where.
Q     Was the synopsis of findings you prepared
for Ms. Corey handwritten or typewritten?
A     It was typed.
Q     How many pages was it?
A     Possibly two.  I don't recall.  I tried
searching for the document, I couldn't find it.  I
didn't have a copy of it.
Q     That's the document that may help refresh
your recollection as to what you did?
A     Probably not.  I'm pretty, you know -- I'm
pretty certain that I remember just about everything
that we did there.
Q     But it's certainly documented what you
learned?
A     Yes.

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Cranston, I'd like a copy

Line.Text: of that.

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  I'll see if we can find

Line.Text: anything.  The witness said he looked for it and
couldn't find anything.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Were there any other documents you
prepared?  I know you said you prepared a property
damage report.
A     Yes.
Q     Is that a form document?
A     It's a form.
Q     And can you just --
A     Paper form.
Q     And is it something that you have as a
field operations supervisor in your files?
A     No.
Q     So where did you obtain the form from?
A     It goes -- we have the blank ones on site
at our office, but once they're filled out, they're
sent to the claims department.
Q     Were they sent to anybody else?
A     No.
Q     So other than what you've provided here
today, that two-page synopsis, and the property
damage report, are you aware of any other documents
relating to this gas fire?
A     No.
Q     Did you talk to anybody else relating to
this gas fire other than Mr. Meza, which I won't ask
you questions about, your conversations, Mr. Youde,
and the two techs that came on the 19th?
A     Are you talking about details of the
incident?
Q     Yeah.
A     In what time frame?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Let me just add, there was

Line.Text: an investigation relating to Mr. Youde, and to the
extent that you're asking about that, the witness is
not going to answer questions concerning that.

Text.#text: But if you're talking about something

Line.Text: other than that the investigation into his actions
as it relates to his employment, again, because of
privacy concerns and other objections that have been
asserted, he can talk as to those discussions.  If
it's not related to the investigation, into his
employment status, then I don't have a problem with
the witness talking about that.

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Okay.

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Now that we've identified that there was
an investigation as to Mr. Youde's employment
status, this is just a yes-no question, were you
involved in any way, shape, or form in that
investigation?
A     Yes.

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  So taking away -- because

Line.Text: of his objections and just so the record is clear,
you would instruct him not to answer on any --

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Right.
MR. RAVIPUDI:  -- of the questions?
MR. WILLIAMS:  Right.
MR. RAVIPUDI:  Okay.
MR. WILLIAMS:  And it goes beyond the

Line.Text: privacy issue as previously stated.  It also
concerns remedial efforts on the part of the Gas
Company.

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  And just so we're clear, I

Line.Text: don't believe that there are any privacy objections
that are outstanding because Mr. Youde hasn't
asserted any and he's waived his right to them.  So
I don't think that's a proper ground for instructing
anybody not to answer or withholding any discovery.

Text.#text: And there's no evidence that this is a

Line.Text: subsequent remedial measure.  Even if it was, it's
still possible and likely to lead to the discovery
of other admissible evidence, so I'm entitled to it.
And I really don't want to bring the witness back,
but I may have to.

Text.#text: Are you going to be maintaining your

Line.Text: objections?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Yeah, I am.

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Okay.  Taking apart -- away any
investigation into the employment or further
employment of Mr. Youde, were there any other
conversations you had with anybody related to this
gas explosion?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Aside from conversations

Line.Text: you had with me or Mr. Meza.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     What I want is, just so it's clear, is I
want just -- it's a yes-no question.
A     Yes.
Q     And if you had conversations with your
lawyer, I'm not going to ask you about them, but you
can ask answer that as a "yes," and then we'll move
on.
A     Right.
Q     So it does include Mr. Meza and it does
include Mr. Williams.
A     As it pertains to the investigation, no.
I mean, I did talk to, you know, with friends,
family, stuff, just getting stress -- it was a
stressful situation for me.  So other than that, no.
Q     Did you ever speak to any occupants of the
premises?
A     Yes.
Q     Do you remember who?
A     I don't.
Q     Do you remember the nature of any such
conversations?
A     The only one that I recall was one of the
females that lived in the -- in the house, in the
front.  She came to us on the night of the 19th
while we were there, and she had a slip in her hand
that she said, oh, the gas company was here earlier.
Q     Okay.
A     And so I said, Okay, let me see that.

Text.#text: So I took it from her and I saw -- that's

Line.Text: when I realized that Simon Youde had been there
earlier.
Q     Got it.  Other than that, do you recall
any other conversations?
A     Not with the tenants, no.  The majority
didn't speak English.
Q     Do you recall any of the conversations you
had with the fire department?
A     I know I spoke to them briefly trying to
obtain a cause, but I don't remember the details of
the conversations.
Q     After you completed your investigation and
spoke to Mr. Youde on the 20th, did you have any
further dialogue with the fire department?
A     No.
Q     Did you ever let the fire department know
of your findings?
A     No.
Q     Do you know if anybody at SoCal Gas let
the fire department know of SoCal Gas's findings?
A     I'm not aware.
Q     Same questions with respect to any -- you
said there was a building inspector there?
A     Yes.
Q     Do you remember his or her name?
A     I don't.
Q     Did you have any dialogue with the
building inspector about your findings?
A     No.
Q     Do you know if anybody at SoCal Gas ever
had any dialogue with the building inspector as to
SoCal Gas's claims?
A     Not that I'm aware of.

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Why don't we go off the

Line.Text: record for a second.

Text.#text: THE VIDEOGRAPHER:  We're now going off the

Line.Text: record.  The time is 11:03.

Text.#text: (Break taken.)
THE VIDEOGRAPHER:  We're now back on the

Line.Text: record.  The time is 11:10.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Couple of housekeeping matters.  So the
last page of Exhibit 4 is a diagram, Bates stamped
SCG 000442; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     And that's identical to Exhibit 3;
correct?
A     Yes, it is.

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  I think I'm just going to

Line.Text: leave it like that.

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Okay.

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Since we've already gone through
Exhibit 3, we've gone through 4222; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     Earlier -- okay.  I think I almost covered
everyone you spoke to while you were at the scene on
the 19th and/or the 20th.  Was there anybody else
you spoke to?
A     The gentleman that appeared to be the
owner -- who stated to be the owner.
Q     Do you remember his name?
A     I do not.
Q     Did you speak to him on the 19th or 20th?
A     Both days.
Q     How many times did you speak to him?
A     That's hard to -- roughly, maybe three
times on the 19th and two or three times on the
20th.
Q     Are you able to separate out each
conversation?
A     No.
Q     Tell me about your conversations with him
on the 19th.
A     I recall asking him if they had any gas
appliances in the back structure.  And he stated
that they did not.
Q     Okay.
A     And once I discovered that valve in the
house by the water heater, I asked him if he knew
that valve controlled gas going to the back.  And I
don't recall what he stated.
Q     Okay.
A     Then, prior to me departing that evening,
I informed him that we were going to return the
following day, and he -- I obtained his phone number
from him and I told him I would call him the
following day to let him know more or less what time
we would arrive.
Q     Did he tell you he'll see you there the
following day?
A     Yes.
Q     So -- it ended on the 19th with the
understanding that you would see each other the
following day?
A     Yes.
Q     With respect to your conversations on the
19th, your question was specific whether there were
any gas appliances in the back; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     Did you ever ask him whether there were
any gas lines or piping connected to the rear house?
A     I must have because I -- that would be
something that I would ask, you know, as part of the
investigation, but I don't recall the conversation.
Q     But on Exhibit 3, you were able to visibly
identify --
A     Yes.
Q     -- gas pipes; correct?
A     Yes.

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Let him finish.

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     So it's obvious there were gas pipes
connected to the rear structure?
A     Yes.

Text.#text: MS. PAPE:  Objection, I'm going to --

Line.Text: objection, calls for speculation, assumes facts not
in evidence, lacks foundation.

Text.#text: THE REPORTER:  What was your answer?  Was

Line.Text: there an answer?

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  His answer was "yes."
Correct?
THE WITNESS:  Yes.

Line.Text: BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     And then you arrived on the 20th and the
premises' owner is -- arrives at some time as well?
A     Yes.
Q     And you called him and told him when you
were coming?
A     Yes.
Q     Tell me about the two or three
conversations you had with the owner on the 20th.
A     I don't recall.
Q     Is there anything of significance
generally that you recall from those conversations?
A     No.
Q     You didn't need his assistance in
conducting your investigation at that point?
A     I probably just informed him we were going
to be there to conduct our investigation, and that
was it.
Q     Okay.  Other than your lawyer, anything
related to the continued employment of Mr. Youde,
and conversations with Mr. Meza, did I cover every
person you spoke with relating to this gas fire?
A     Yes.
Q     And other -- now let's go to the
photographs, Exhibit 4.  I think there was maybe a
misstatement by me on the record.  I just want to
clarify it.  Exhibit 4, Bates stamped SCG 417 and
418 are what depict the open gas line that was
opened by Mr. Youde that led to the gas fire in the
rear structure; correct?
A     Yes.
Q     Okay.  When we were off the record, I
asked you to flip through your photographs marked as
Exhibit 4 and then I would ask you about any
photographs where you were documenting something
that was of significance to you.

Text.#text: Were you able to do that off the record?

Line.Text: A     I looked at the photographs, but I'm still
a little unclear as to what you were trying to --
Q     Yeah.  Just looking, for example, at the
first photograph of Exhibit 4, 393 --
A     Yes.
Q     -- sometimes photographs are taken just to
capture the state of the premises and sometimes
they're taken because you've identified something
that's of significance to you in your investigation.
A     Okay.
Q     And if you look at 417 and 418, those
photographs were not just taken to capture the
existence of the premises, but because you were able
to find the valve that was opened that led to the
leak --
A     Yes.
Q     -- right?

Text.#text: Were there any other types of photographs

Line.Text: that were taken by you to document things of
significance in your investigation?
A     The photograph, 00393, depicts a half-inch
steel gas line, a gas shutoff valve, and a yellow
flexible gas connector that was discovered behind
that wall.
Q     And this is what's -- so 393 is
documenting your diagram notations on Exhibit 3?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     And this is on the outside of the
structure or the inside?
A     This is on the outside.
Q     Okay.  Carry on.  Sorry, just going back
to 393, this was a photograph taken on the 20th?
A     Yes, sir.
Q     Were all of the photographs taken on the
20th?
A     I believe so.  I believe so.
Q     I'm not exactly sure how these were
produced, but is it fair to say, to the best of your
recollection, that 393 is the first photograph you
clicked with your camera and 421 is the last
photograph?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Just so the witness is

Line.Text: aware, I don't know that any attempt was made to
keep any order in connection with the Bates
numbering, so you need to take a look at them
yourself to see if that is the case.

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  Okay.  I really don't recall

Line.Text: the sequence of the photographs.
BY MR. RAVIPUDI:
Q     Now, going through the photographs, you've
identified 393 which documents some of your
notations on Exhibit 3.

Text.#text: What else?

Line.Text: A     394 was an attempt to depict the half-inch
steel gas pipe that ultimately leads to the valve
and flexible connectors shown in 393.
Q     So basically, you can see in 393, there's
a wooden structure --
A     Yes.
Q     -- and then the actual rear of the
structure of the house, and you sort of stood in
between there and took the photograph?
A     Yes.
Q     And that's what's in 394?
A     Yes.
Q     Same with 395?
A     Yes.

Text.#text: 397 also shows that -- you can't see the

Line.Text: valve but you can see the yellow connector.
Q     Okay.
A     In the same position in the previous
picture, just a further-away shot.

Text.#text: 407 is a pack of cigarettes that was

Line.Text: nearby in the yard to where somebody had stated that
the gentleman that was -- that received the burns
was lighting a cigarette.
Q     So does -- do you know if these were the
cigarettes that were on the gentleman?
A     I don't know.
Q     So it's just identifying some cigarettes
on the ground?
A     Yes.
Q     Okay.
A     408 was a picture of a lighter that was
near the cigarettes on the floor.
Q     Do you have any knowledge whether this was
the lighter utilized?
A     I do not.

Text.#text: 409 shows a -- a copper water connector to

Line.Text: where you would assume that there was a water heater
at one point.
Q     But you were not able to identify any
water heater in the rear structure; correct?
A     I did not see a water heater.

Text.#text: 410 appears to be the hooded sweatshirt

Line.Text: the gentleman was wearing when he received the
burns.
Q     Do you know that or is it just your
assumption?
A     That's my assumption.
Q     Did you take these photographs of the
newspaper?
A     Yes, 411, 412, and 413, and 414 are
photographs that I took of the local newspaper that
one of the tenants had on the 20th.
Q     Okay.
A     415 is the water heater that Simon Youde
serviced in the front house -- front structure.

Text.#text: 416 is a picture of the water heater.

Line.Text: It's difficult to see but you can see the actual
valve that was turned "on" on the left side of that
picture.
Q     Was anything moved in order for you to
take this photograph?
A     Yes, the refrigerator.
Q     Okay.
A     417 and 418 are front photographs of the
valve -- the gas valve to the water heater and the
gas valve supplying gas to the rear structure.

Text.#text: 419 is just a picture of the water heater.

Line.Text: Q     You kind of see a little bit to the left
of the water heater, is that the valve also?
A     Yes.
Q     Okay.
A     You can see the yellow valve that serves
the water heater.  The other valve, you can't see on
there.
Q     Okay.  Do you know what 420 is?
A     420 appears to be the gas line, either
going to the fireplace or to the wall furnace that
they have, I don't recall.
Q     Okay.  Is there anything of significance
in 420 to you?
A     No, not that I can tell here.
Q     421 looks like the fireplace or -- I don't
even know why I --
A     Yeah, 420 --
Q     One?
A     421, I'm sorry, is the fireplace, and it
has that flexible gas connector going through the
brick.  And you could see on the right, the valve is
turned off.  And to the right of that is the wall
furnace, so the gas continues towards the right
serving the wall furnace.  So that's what the
picture on 420 depicts.
Q     Is that an unsatisfactory condition?
A     The connector going through the brick,
yes.
Q     That was obvious to you during your
walk-through?
A     Yes.
Q     Okay.  I don't think I have any further
questions at this time.

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Kara, do you have any

Line.Text: questions?

Text.#text: MS. PAPE:  I do.
MR. RAVIPUDI:  Just to note, the video has

Line.Text: three minutes left.  Should we switch it out?

Text.#text: MS. PAPE:  Yeah, it's probably best.
THE VIDEOGRAPHER:  This marks the end of

Line.Text: Tape 1 in the deposition of Marcell Escobar.  We're
now going off the record.  The time is 11:28.

Text.#text: (Break taken.)
THE VIDEOGRAPHER:  This now begins Tape 2

Line.Text: in the deposition of Marcell Escobar.  We're now
back on the record.  The time is 11:34.

Text.#text: EXAMINATION

Line.Text: BY MS. PAPE:
Q     Mr. Escobar, I just have a few questions
to follow up with you.

Text.#text: This two-page synopsis you indicated you

Line.Text: prepared following your inspection, did it contain
any conversations you may have had with the
gentleman you believed was the landlord or the owner
of the property?
A     I don't believe it did.
Q     When is the last time you saw that
two-page synopsis that you prepared?
A     Probably the day I submitted it to my
boss, 20th or the 21st.
Q     I think you indicated that it was the
evening of the 19th when you were approached by the
female occupant of the main house who told you that
someone from the Gas Company had been there earlier
in the day?
A     Yes.
Q     Prior to being approached by that female
occupant of the main house, had you been informed by
anyone that someone from the Gas Company had, in
fact, serviced the property earlier that day?
A     No.
Q     Were you surprised to learn this, that
someone had been there earlier that day from the Gas
Company?

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Objection on the grounds

Line.Text: that the question is vague and ambiguous, calls for
speculation.  But you can answer.

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  Of course.

Line.Text: BY MS. PAPE:
Q     Did Mr. Youde prepare any paperwork
following his service of the property before
January 20th?
A     Prepare any paperwork before the 20th?
Q     Yes.
A     So, during his service order on the 19th?
Q     Yes.

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  Do you know if he did?
THE WITNESS:  He must have because that

Line.Text: tenant had a copy of something, and I don't recall
what it is.  Let me look at this order to see if
it -- yes, he provided them a receipt for our
seismic restorer charge.  And that's the receipt
that she showed me.
BY MS. PAPE:
Q     Is that the extent of any paperwork that
Mr. Youde prepared as far as you are aware for his
servicing of the property on the 19th?
A     According to his order, yes.
Q     To your knowledge, did Mr. Youde document
any unsatisfactory condition in the main house
before his visit to the property on January 20th?
A     No, he did not.
Q     Okay.  You told us about the yellow knob
and the tubing that is documented in Photograph 418;
do you recall that?
A     Yes.
Q     And did you see that yellow knob and
tubing on both the 19th and the 20th --
A     Yes.
Q     -- when you were at the scene?
A     Yes, I did.
Q     Did you or anyone from the Gas Company
take any evidence with you when you left the scene?
A     No.

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  When you say "evidence,"

Line.Text: you're talking about something physical from the
scene as opposed to pictures and things like that?

Text.#text: MS. PAPE:  Correct.
THE WITNESS:  No, I did not -- no, we did

Line.Text: not.
BY MS. PAPE:
Q     Why did you ask Mr. Youde to return to the
scene on the 20th?
A     I was instructed by our claims advisor,
Manny Meza, to bring him back to the scene because
he wanted to talk to him, for one, and we also
needed to conclude our leak investigation.
Q     Did you ever -- strike that.

Text.#text: Do you recall ever speaking to a gentleman

Line.Text: by the name of Yongsheng Li.  The spelling for that
is Y-o-n-g-s-h-e-n-g, last name, L-i.
A     The name doesn't sound familiar.
Q     You told us there was a code inspector at
the property?
A     Yes.
Q     At some point when you were there; is that
correct?
A     Yes.
Q     Did you ever get a business card from that
person?
A     No, I did not.
Q     And if you testified about this before, I
apologize for going into it in any more detail, but
do you recall any specific conversation you may have
had with this person?
A     I didn't speak with him directly.
Q     Okay.  This diagram that you prepared --
A     Yes.
Q     -- you prepared that on the 20th?
January 20th?
A     I believe it was the 20th.
Q     And did you prepare this diagram after
speaking with Mr. Youde about what happened during
his service of the property?
A     Yes.
Q     And did any information that you obtained
from speaking with Mr. Youde, is that set forth in
the diagram?
A     No, everything on the diagram is what I
witnessed on scene.
Q     That you personally observed?
A     Yes.
Q     Did you prepare any notes while you were
at the scene that you then transferred to this
diagram?
A     Not that I recall.
Q     Did anyone assist you in preparing this
diagram?
A     No.
Q     Were you contacted by anyone from the fire
department after January 20th?
A     I was not.

Text.#text: MS. PAPE:  Okay.  I don't think I have any

Line.Text: other questions.  Thank you.

Text.#text: MR. RAVIPUDI:  Do you have any?
MR. WILLIAMS:  No.
MR. RAVIPUDI:  Thank you very much for

Line.Text: your time.

Text.#text: THE WITNESS:  Thank you.
MR. RAVIPUDI:  I propose we relieve the

Line.Text: court reporter of his duty under the Code with
respect to maintaining the original transcript.

Text.#text: Upon its completion, it will be forwarded

Line.Text: to Mr. Williams' office, who will make it available
for the witness to review.  The witness will have
30 days upon Mr. Williams' receipt of the
transcript, to review it, sign it, make any changes.
Within that same time period Mr. Williams will
notify all counsel that the original has been signed
and of any changes being made.

Text.#text: If no notification is received within that

Line.Text: time period, the original will be presumed to have
been signed with no changes.  And Mr. Williams can
retain copy of the original and make it available
upon request.  In the event it's unavailable for any
reason, a certified copy can be treated as the same.

Text.#text: MR. WILLIAMS:  So stipulated.
MS. PAPE:  So stipulated.
THE VIDEOGRAPHER:  Before we go off the

Line.Text: record, would anyone be interested in a copy of the
video?

Text.#text: MS. PAPE:  Yes.
MR. WILLIAMS:  Yes.
THE VIDEOGRAPHER:  And what about the

Line.Text: transcript?

Text.#text: Copy of the transcript?
MS. PAPE:  Yes.
MR. WILLIAMS:  I'm getting it, too.

Line.Text: They're sending me.

Text.#text: THE VIDEOGRAPHER:  Thank you.  This now

Line.Text: concludes today's deposition of Marcell Escobar.
We're now going off the record.  The time is 11:44.
